data.title: What is happening with Windows Phone 8.1 ?
data.body:
Hello,

I'd like to reopen this issue with some proof that CompositionTarget.Rendering is totally broken on WP8.1 (and WP10 at some extent)
- Using VS2013, crete new Visual C# -> Store Apps -> Universal Apps project. Blank App
- Add function to MainPage.xaml.cs
  
  ```
  void renderingFunc (object sender,object args)
  {
      renderingCount++;
  }
  ```
- Add CompositionTarget.Rendering+=renderingFunc; to the MainPage constructor.
- Add a button to the XAML and a textblock in order to print stuff. Associate this function to the button
  
  ```
  private void Button_Click(object sender, RoutedEventArgs e)
  {
      textBlock.Text=String.Format ("Rendering calls: {0}",renderingCount);
  }
  ```
- Run on WP8.1 device (mine is Nokia 920 , latest firmware update).Tapping the button will print the number of times Rendering has been called
- Now mash the screen with all fingers, tapping and dragging. Admitely it takes some more time than MonoGame to crash, but I can make it crash in 10-15 seconds
- Now tap the button. Tap no longer works.

OK, now the weird part. I was writing this message to show the evilness of CompositionTarget.Rendering, affecting touch, adding a huge delay to screen rotation, increasing global warming and in WP10 I think it's the culprit that sometimes randomly the touch locations are 'portrait' when should be 'landscape'.  When I thought... this is weird, I can't see why subscribing to CompositionTarget can affect this.

So, at the previous message I removed everything related to CompositionTarget, and incremented the counter each time the button was pushed. Guess what? WP8.1 still stops receiving touches.

So, creating a simple XAML app, adding a button, and mashing, makes the button (and all touch) stop working in my Nokia 920.

So, my question is... is it just an issue with my Nokia 920 or is somebody else able to reproduce this problem? Because it seems that everything with XAML in it is freezing when mashing the screen in WP8.1 mode (not a problem in WP8.0) 

EDIT: I've seen several WP8.1 only games freezing under those conditions, and apparently not using MonoGame at all, which would confirm that everything-XAML based on my Nokia 920 is affected by this problem.

data.title: Fix premature access on possibly null variable
Fix copy-paste error in network statistics.
Windows DirectX VideoPlayer leaks large amounts of memory
data.body:
Each WMV video played would leak about 75MB of memory, rapidly increasing the amount used by the software, with disposing the videos doing nothing, even after PlatformDispose was uncommented in Video.cs.

I spent a while looking into it and came to the conclusion that the cleanup process wasn't being handled correctly; MediaFoundation documentation at https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms703190(v=vs.85).aspx describes an asynchronous process of closing the session that needs to be done before the media source, then session is disposed. I couldn't find any documentation for disposing media sources without closing the session they had been used with.

I came up with a first draft for a set of changes to fix this, using #4090's work on MediaPlayer as a starting point, which move the MediaSession into the Video class and have a MediaSession per video, which is closed, followed by disposal of the rest of the resources, when the video is disposed. They also dispose events received by our callback class, since not doing so causes the leak to persist, which is something that likely wants to be incorporated in any fixes to MediaPlayer's disposing of resources, too. The changes are at https://github.com/jbeshir/MonoGame/tree/video-player-rework but this isn't suitable to merge because of some remaining issues I encountered while working on it:
- The TaskScheduler-based dispatching to the UI thread used in #4090 didn't seem to be working right for me, it was running things on the thread pool, so I had to incorporate the same approach to passing tasks off to the UI thread used on Android. I suspect this could have been caused in some fashion by the particular product I was testing with, though.
- Because it needs to invoke to the UI thread several times to raise events before the video enters the playing state after a call to PlatformPlay, the loop waiting for the session to enter the playing state in Play always fails. I'm not sure the best way to deal with this, but this might not be a problem if the above is fixed since it sleeps in Play and .NET pumps the message queue while sleeping/blocked on a lock by default.

(In our own fork I worked around this by adding a PlayAsync method to VideoPlayer.cs, which dropped the loop-and-sleep-until-state-changed behaviour entirely, since it was desirable to make things smoother anyway by letting the rest of the program continue while the video setup happened, but this didn't fix the XNA compatible API and I've not included it in the linked branch.)

data.title: GamePad not working on Windows 7 / DirectX
data.body:
Hey there,

We are testing our game against several configurations and it appears that gamepads are no more working on Windows 7 and Vista (DirectX target).

They are correctly installed but are not detected in MonoGame. There is no crash related to any XInput version mismatch. The game works correctly but gamepad can not be pooled.

Installing a previous DirectX redist (XInput 1.3) doesn't change this.

My wild guess is that SharpDX loads XInput 9.1.0 (compatibility mode) if it can't find XInput 1.4 (Win8) and that the 9.1.0 is lacking some features useful to MonoGame.

Or am I missing a dependency?

EDIT: may be related to #3240 (and just noticed that I already pop'd that discussion over there...).

data.title: Please update the Current Roadmap
data.body:
It seems like at least these three are done:

> - The MonoGame 2.x series is now in maintenance mode.
> - MonoGame 3.0 will mark the start of full support for the entire XNA API.
> - The Content Pipeline is currently under development. This will allow compiling of assets to optimized formats for the MonoGame supported platforms in Visual Studio or MonoDevelop without requiring XNA Game Studio 4.0 installed.

It would be great to mention the status of the official PCL package which is in pre-release and a couple of releases behind: https://www.nuget.org/packages/MonoGame.Framework.Portable. It is not immediately obvious what is the plan even based on the discussion #3405 (which is lengthy).

data.title: Feature proposal: content encryption
data.body:
Hello there,

For our coming title, we are using licensed assets and their license obliges us to "not make the assets easily readable from the game files". Which means that we are contractually bound to obfuscate in some sort a few files. While XNB packaging/compression is fine for most asset types, it isn't for Song, because this type of assets is not embedded in XNB.

Since it's something out of the scope of the original XNA, I would like to have your opinion if that would make a good feature to add to MonoGame. It isn't a trivial task so if not, we'll most likely don't bother integrating that feature deeply into MonoGame and just do some custom encryption of song files on platforms where they can be browsed.

data.title: Fix for NullReferenceException when trying to switch Song rapidly
data.body:
Due to the async volume controller initialization in XAudio, it may happen that switching rapidly songs can trigger a null ref exception here (because the volume has not been init yet): https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/03185dff502df8532600fadbe8044b3d3c978d2d/MonoGame.Framework/Media/MediaPlayer.WMS.cs#L155

This PR adds null checks to MediaPlayer and VideoPlayer to cope with the async init.

data.title: Fix multitouch lockup on WP8.1
data.body:
Use a RunLoop thread rather than listening for `CompositionTarget.Rendering`.
This seems to fix the lockup during touch on WP8.1.

I needed to add a lock around the orientation event otherwise we could try change orientation while drawing and we'd crash (because the run loop runs at the same time).
I don't think anywhere else needs the same lock, but I may of overlooked something.

I haven't changed the input code, so we still get 60 touches a second for every touch that is occurring. This doesn't seem to cause troubles for me, but may on bigger projects (I'm testing on a lumia 520 though, so it is pretty slow)

This will need testing on other Metro platforms too (Win8 Store app), I'll try have a crack later today, I don't expect any troubles though.

Fixes #3316
